source_notes: Pilot episode. Father (Vietnam medic) accuses ER doctors of killing his daughter who came in with sore throat.
summary: Suzanne Morton dies in ER after being given meperidine by drunk Dr. Auster, which fatally interacted with her phenelzine (antidepressant). Dr. Ekballa Raza initially suspected but proven innocent when investigation reveals he wrote correct drug (acetaminophen) and falsified chart under pressure. Raza faced public scrutiny and career threats as foreign doctor before being cleared.

source_notes: Transcript shows Laura di Biasi shoots two young men on subway after perceived threat. Michael Jones (aka Mosquito Mosket) dies; Darnell Chenault paralyzed. Case revolves around self-defense vs. premeditated revenge.
summary: Laura di Biasi, a former dancer turned hospital technician, shoots two young men (Darnell Chenault and Michael Jones/Mosket) on a subway after they allegedly threaten her. She claims self-defense; prosecution argues premeditated revenge stemming from a prior subway attack that ended her dance career. Jones/Mosket dies. The case focuses on di Biasi as defendant throughout—no falsely accused innocent parties are identified. Prosecution eventually offers a plea deal when new information about Mosket's criminal history creates reasonable doubt on murder charges. No person in this episode meets the criteria of being publicly accused then proven/strongly implied innocent.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete with full courtroom scenes and investigation details.
summary: Jack Curry is arrested and prosecuted for the murder of Bobby Holland, a gay man with AIDS. Curry admits to pulling the trigger but claims it was assisted suicide - that Holland wanted to die rather than suffer from AIDS. The prosecution argues Curry committed murder regardless of Holland's wishes. While Curry was initially suspected of serial murder (similar cases in LA and San Francisco), all three victims had AIDS and evidence suggests Holland may have wanted to die (he trashed his own apartment, paid off debts). However, Holland also had an appointment to discuss AZT treatment, suggesting he wanted to live. Ultimately, the jury acquits Curry of murder/manslaughter but convicts on reckless endangerment (a misdemeanor). No one in this episode is falsely accused and later proven innocent - Curry did pull the trigger on all three victims, the question was whether it constituted murder or assisted suicide.

episode_title: Kiss the Girls and Make Them Die
source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Paige Bartlett is strangled in her apartment. Two men had sexual contact with her that night: Steve Feinstein (ponytail boyfriend who dumped her) and Ned Loomis (ex-boyfriend who was with her later). Feinstein is initially suspected but has a solid alibi. Loomis is convicted of her murder. Steve Feinstein was publicly accused of murder, questioned by detectives multiple times, and labeled a suspect despite his alibi, causing exposure at his workplace and among his social circle before being cleared.

source_notes: Classic Law & Order format with clear investigation pivot from Willie Tivnan to Janet Ralston and Gil Himes
summary: Alan Ralston is murdered in a parking garage. Willie Tivnan, a Black man with a criminal record, is arrested after his fingerprints are found on a crack pipe at the scene and Janet Ralston identifies him. However, detectives discover evidence pointing to Janet Ralston and her lover Gil Himes as the actual killers who planned the murder for insurance money. Willie is eventually cleared, but only after being publicly accused, arrested, and held on $100,000 bail.

source_notes: Full transcript available. Episode involves a conspiracy to murder Charles Halsey, who was serving as a bagman for corrupt officials. Two young black men initially accused.
summary: Councilman Charles Halsey is stabbed and later dies. Two black teenagers (Simonize Jackson and Tremaine Lewis) are initially arrested for the attack after being found with his possessions. They confess to robbery but claim Halsey was already wounded when they arrived. Investigation reveals Halsey was a bagman in a municipal corruption scheme. Anthony Scalisi (mob enforcer) actually stabbed Halsey on orders from corrupt officials (Deputy Commander Jefferson, Borough President Conti, Councilman Van Damme). The two teenagers were innocent of the stabbing, only guilty of robbery of an already-wounded man.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete with full courtroom and detective scenes.
summary: Irv Diamond dies after a heart attack while with prostitute Jolene Curtis. Driver Cookie Molina removes Diamond from the hotel, dumps him in Central Park, and hits him with a bat to fake a mugging. Investigation leads to Laura Winthrop's high-end prostitution ring 'Poppy Escorts.' Jolene is HIV-positive, raising reckless endangerment concerns. Cookie testifies against Winthrop in exchange for a walk. Winthrop ultimately pleads to involuntary manslaughter. No person was falsely accused then cleared - Diamond's death investigation correctly identified those responsible (Cookie, Jolene, Winthrop). The case focused on prosecuting the actual perpetrators of the prostitution ring and Diamond's death.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: Officer Freddo Parisi shoots Tommy Richardson, a Princeton student, claiming self-defense during a drug deal. Investigation reveals Richardson never had a gun—Parisi planted his weapon after the shooting. Silky Ford, who sold the gun, is initially misidentified but protected by Parisi's threats. Partner Davis covers for Parisi until confronted with evidence. Richardson is publicly portrayed as a drug dealer during investigation/trial, destroying his reputation as a community hero. Parisi commits suicide before verdict.

source_notes: Transcript of Law & Order S1E9. Episode focuses on child abuse case involving Dierdre 'Didi' Lowenstein. Both parents are accused and tried; mother Carla confesses and pleads to manslaughter, testifies against husband Jacob who is convicted of murder.
summary: No qualifying persons found. Both Carla and Jacob Lowenstein were accused of murdering their daughter Didi, and both were ultimately convicted (Carla of manslaughter via plea, Jacob of murder). Neither was proven or strongly implied innocent. The episode's focus is on the tragic death of an abused child and the prosecution of both parents responsible for her death. No false suspects or wrongly accused individuals appear in the transcript.

source_notes: Transcript analyzed for false accusation patterns
summary: Artist Victor More dies during a sexual asphyxiation session. Commissioner Henry Rothman is charged with manslaughter after his fingerprint is found on a Polaroid taken during More's death. Evidence shows Elizabeth Hendrick, a wealthy patron, was present and ordered Rothman not to save More. Rothman initially testifies against Hendrick, then recants under her influence and commits suicide. Hendrick is ultimately arrested based on Polaroids Rothman left behind. No individuals were falsely accused and later proven innocent; the investigation correctly identified the perpetrators.

source_notes: Transcript shows a 16-year-old girl claims to have been raped by white police officers. Investigation reveals she fabricated the story to get permission for an abortion (she was pregnant by boyfriend Jordan Hill). Congressman Eaton uses the case for political purposes. FBI rape kit comes back negative. Girl and mother eventually admit the hoax.
summary: Astrea Crawford, 16, claims white police officers raped her and wrote racial slurs on her body. Two uniformed officers (Teal and Rudolph) are publicly named by Congressman Eaton. Investigation reveals the rape never occurred - Astrea fabricated the story because she was pregnant by boyfriend Jordan Hill and wanted an abortion but feared her father's reaction. FBI rape kit negative. Officers Teal and Rudolph are cleared with substantiated alibis. Case becomes politically charged with Congressman Eaton using it to attack the justice system, despite knowing or suspecting it was false.

source_notes: Abortion clinic bombing; Mary Donovan dies delivering bomb she thought would be set at night; revealed she was actually seeking abortion
summary: Anti-abortion activists Rose Schwimmer and Celeste McClure conspire to bomb Chelsea Women's Choices clinic. Mary Donovan, believing she's delivering a bomb for the cause, dies in the explosion. Investigation reveals Mary was actually pregnant and seeking an abortion under a false ID provided by her boyfriend Patrick Dunn. Patrick is briefly arrested as co-conspirator based on fingerprints on the fake ID, but he was actually helping Mary get an abortion, not plant a bomb. The episode explores the abortion debate while prosecuting Schwimmer and McClure for murder.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Officer Rennick, a corrupt cop who was skimming money from drug busts and killed dealer Ricky Powers, attempts to murder his partner Officer Sandoval on a rooftop to silence her. She kills him in self-defense. Brutus Walker is initially suspected of killing Rennick but is later cleared. A 15-year-old girl, Ravina Price, is briefly suspected when her fingerprints are found on the murder weapon. The episode explores police corruption and the breakdown of the partner bond.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Three young men (Metzler, Hanauer, and Ryan Cutrona) are accused of gang-raping reporter Monica DeVries. The case is dismissed due to victim's repressed memory and lack of DNA match. Investigation reveals a fourth perpetrator, Timothy Pruiting, who actually committed the rape while the three younger defendants primarily held the victim. Ryan Cutrona, the youngest and most reluctant participant, eventually testifies against Pruiting. The three younger men are re-arrested for rape (holding/accessory roles), but they are factually less culpable than initially accused of being the primary rapists.

source_notes: This is Part 1 of a two-part episode. Resolution likely occurs in Part 2.
summary: Isaac Skolnick is brutally beaten in his candy store over a bootlegged cigarette conspiracy. Edgar Hoover, a homeless man, is initially accused but later cleared when the real attacker (Joe Pilefsky) is identified. Hoover dies shortly after. The case expands into organized crime involving the Masucci family. Harvey Beigal cuts a deal to testify about a separate murder (Russell Mackey), which allows him to walk on the Skolnick assault conspiracy despite being the one who ordered it. The Mackey case collapses due to perjured testimony from Pilefsky (part of Masucci's strategy), and Beigal's plea bargain stands despite the outcome.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete. This is Part 2 of a multi-part episode dealing with organized crime.
summary: Following a failed prosecution of mob boss Frank Masucci for murder (set up via perjured testimony in Part 1), Stone pursues various members of the Masucci crime family. Laurel McGinty, a buildings inspector, is accused of bribery and threatened with prosecution to flip on Harvey Beigal (Masucci's brother-in-law). She is proven innocent of the primary crime narrative (the murders) but guilty of the bribery she's accused of. Joe Pilefsky is coerced through threats and a staged prison incident into cooperating. The episode culminates with Masucci being murdered, orchestrated by his own sister Katherine Beigal.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: An 11-month-old baby is killed and his 12-year-old brother critically wounded in a drive-by shooting. Police initially suspect the older brother Gregory Winters of drug dealing, but he is proven innocent. The real crime was a botched contract killing by drug dealer Michael Ingrams against real estate agent Ned Kay, who stole $300,000 from him. The 14-year-old hit man went to the wrong apartment (315 Jacobs Place instead of 315 Jameson Place).

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-trial
summary: Jose Urbano, a drug dealer and parolee, is shot at a church fair. Initially, Hector Cartagena (Urbano's associate) is suspected and arrested. However, evidence later reveals that Nicky Guzman shot Urbano in revenge for raping Guzman's fiancée Lucy Rivers. Alicia Rivers (Lucy's sister) is also arrested for conspiracy but charges are dismissed. Both Cartagena and Alicia are publicly accused but later cleared. The transcript ends mid-trial for Nicky Guzman.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial and arrest of Petrovich.
summary: Karl and Evelyn Jarmon are murdered in their home. Their sons Greg and Nick are arrested based on fingerprints on the murder weapon, powder residue, financial motive ($10M inheritance), and weak alibi. The boys had history of abuse from their father. Later investigation reveals business partner Alex Petrovich orchestrated the murders as part of Russian organized crime scheme to take over Jarmon Printing. Charges against the sons are dropped; Petrovich is convicted.

source_notes: Transcript shows Law & Order S1E20 'The Troubles' involving IRA member Ian O'Connell and federal prisoners.
summary: A federal prisoner (Ahmed Mustafa) is murdered while in transit. Initially both surviving prisoners (Savino Montez and Ian O'Connell) are suspects. Montez is later found hanged in his cell, initially staged as suicide but proven to be murder by prison guard Patrick McCarter on O'Connell's orders. O'Connell, an IRA member held for 5 years without charges, is eventually prosecuted for Mustafa's murder after being granted asylum. Multiple people experience serious consequences from accusations before being cleared or shown innocent.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete with full courtroom resolution.
summary: Drew MacDaniel is found in Central Park missing a kidney, which was illegally harvested and transplanted into Joanna Woodleigh. Dr. James Reberty and nurse Elaine Hale are arrested for the crime. While Reberty initially tries to shift blame to Hale, both are eventually convicted. Phillip Woodleigh (Joanna's father) is also prosecuted for conspiracy after evidence shows he knowingly paid for the illegal organ procurement. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies the perpetrators from the start.

source_notes: Transcript shows a case about evidence tampering in a money laundering prosecution. Three bankers were acquitted after computer discs showing drug money trails were erased. Investigation reveals conspiracy involving Congressman Wilson, Chief O'Farrell, Officer McCrory, and Detective Shearer.
summary: Three bankers accused of money laundering were acquitted after evidence (computer discs) was tampered with. Captain Cragen was investigated and publicly suspected by IAD but proven innocent when he wore a wire that implicated Chief O'Farrell. The actual conspirators were O'Farrell, Congressman Wilson, McCrory, and Shearer.

source_notes: Transcript involves Det. Max Greevey's murder investigation and subsequent coerced confession by Det. Mike Logan.
summary: Detective Max Greevey is murdered before testifying in a grand jury corruption case. His partner Mike Logan tracks down and coerces a confession from Daniel Magadan Jr. at gunpoint in an alley. Though Magadan confessed and was ultimately convicted, the confession was coerced under threat of death. The episode focuses on the legal consequences of Logan's conduct and the admissibility of evidence derived from the coerced confession. Magadan is convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to 25 years to life.

source_notes: Transcript analyzed per rubric
summary: Edward Cullen and his girlfriend Alexandra Beckett are murdered. Doug Phillips, Alexandra's ex-boyfriend, is arrested based on prints, motive (jealousy), and phone records. He is later cleared when evidence shows Melanie Cullen (Edward's estranged wife) committed the murders. Phillips was publicly arrested and indicted before being cleared.

source_notes: 19-year-old actress Priscilla Blaine dies from amitriptyline overdose (200+ mg, 8+ tablets). Her mother Elizabeth Blaine pushed her into pornography to fulfill her own failed acting dreams. Priscilla left a desperate taped monologue for her mother a week before death. Mother is convicted of criminally negligent homicide.
summary: No falsely accused innocent persons are identified in this episode. The investigation consistently focuses on the victim's mother, Elizabeth Blaine, who is ultimately convicted. While the legal theory shifts from suicide to accidental overdose during trial, no other suspects are pursued or publicly accused then cleared. This is a case about parental pressure leading to death, not mistaken identification.

source_notes: Nathan Robbins stabbed to death during street robbery. Christian Tatum ('Lemonhead') initially accused, later cleared. James Polesky convicted.
summary: Nathan Robbins is stabbed to death outside a coffee shop. Christian Tatum ('Lemonhead'), a homeless man with severe mental illness, is arrested when police find the victim's ring in his jacket pocket. He claims his friend 'James' did the stabbing. Investigation proves James Polesky committed the murder; Tatum accepts plea deal and testifies against Polesky. Tatum suffers severe mental deterioration from trial stress and anti-psychotic medication, ending up institutionalized at Bellevue in a 'rubber cell.'

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial testimony.
summary: Parents Ted and Nancy Driscoll are charged with manslaughter after their daughter Dinah dies from untreated strep throat due to their religious beliefs forbidding medical treatment. The case focuses on their Church of All Saints faith in spiritual healing. There are no falsely accused innocent parties—the parents are the defendants throughout, and while the prosecution struggles with proving their guilt, they are never cleared or replaced by other suspects. The housekeeper Mrs. Amado and church practitioner Sharon Barlow are witnesses, not accused persons.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated at final cross-examination
summary: Amy Newhouse is attacked and loses her pregnancy. Initially, detectives suspect her boyfriend Chris (a former disbarred lawyer turned cabbie). Evidence later points to her boss David Alcott, with whom she had an affair. Alcott is arrested and publicly tried for murder, then assault. Eventually it's revealed Amy and Chris orchestrated the entire scheme: Chris was the actual father (not Alcott), they blackmailed Alcott, then staged the attack themselves to file a civil suit. The transcript cuts off during Amy's cross-examination about whether they knew the legal definition of murder in NY.

source_notes: Episode involves a 30-year-old cold case; victim Tommy Keegan, age 8, killed in 1962; remains found in 1992/1993
summary: Two men (Dorfman and Conover) living in the same building as victim Tommy Keegan were suspected by police and neighbors after the boy's 1962 disappearance. Ed Conover faced public suspicion and a separate accusation of approaching a boy at a church youth group. Both men were innocent; the actual killer was Thaddeus Messimer, the father of Tommy's friend Julie, who pled guilty 31 years later.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial verdict
summary: Andrea Fermi accuses fraternity members Ted Campion and Joel Holder of gang rape at a Halloween party. The case involves extensive investigation and trial, ending with both defendants acquitted. Andrea herself is not proven innocent of any accusation - she is the accuser/victim. Her ex-boyfriend Gary Burnham initially lies but cooperates after plea deal. No person in this episode qualifies as falsely accused then proven innocent with public harm.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: A bartender is killed in a hit-and-run. Investigation reveals his wife Jenna Kealey was having an affair with her 16-year-old student Roy Pack. Roy confesses to the murder, claiming Jenna manipulated him. Jenna claims she tried to hire a hit man (David Kaufer) but renounced the plan, and that Roy acted alone out of obsession. However, the prosecution discovers Kaufer was lying - Jenna paid him to pretend to be a hit man to manipulate Roy into committing the murder, creating a false renunciation story as insurance. Both Roy and Jenna are guilty - Roy of the actual killing, Jenna of conspiracy and manipulation.

source_notes: Transcript of Law & Order S2E10. 53 people died in an arson attack on a social club (El Cielo). Investigation reveals conspiracy involving forged green cards.
summary: An arson attack on El Cielo social club kills 53 people. Police initially suspect Guillermo Ruiz, a drunk ex-boyfriend of a barmaid who threatened the club. Ruiz is brought in for questioning and his apartment searched, but his landlord provides an alibi (he was home asleep by 11:30). Investigation shifts to arson-for-profit targeting club owner Jose Rivera/Marcos, but Marcos dies in the fire. Police then identify Cesar Pescador through stolen green card use at hospital. Pescador confesses he was hired by Domingo Guerra to send a 'message' to Salvadorans who were threatening to expose Guerra's forged green card scheme. Guerra and INS agent James Collins are ultimately charged with the murders.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated at end during tape playback
summary: Broadway producer Joshua Foster is found murdered, frozen for 5 years. Investigation reveals he was killed by his fiancée Leslie Hart and partner Gary Wallace after threatening to expose drug money funding their show. Mario Forcelli is initially investigated as mob-connected, but cleared. Both Hart and Wallace are publicly exposed through arrest, indictment, and trial.

source_notes: SVU episode, not original Law & Order. Transcript shows opening with SVU intro ('sexually-based offenses'). Victim Marnie Owens is a teacher murdered after sexual assault. Main suspect Phillip Montrose eventually indicted for manslaughter.
summary: High school teacher Marnie Owens is raped and murdered. Multiple people are investigated and publicly exposed before Phillip Montrose is indicted. Ethan Chance, a student, is wrongly accused and arrested publicly. Dr. Byron Marks is interrogated and exposed. Marcus Cole is questioned. All are later cleared when evidence points to Montrose, who eventually gets indicted for manslaughter (not murder) after testimony about victim's sexual history influences grand jury.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial/plea resolution
summary: Professional hitman Frank Kemp murders bookkeeper Janet Torrens (who was cooperating with FBI against defense contractor Charles Martine) plus two advertising executives (Craig Hovis and Peter Coyle) who witnessed the killing. Lawyer Larry Teasdale served as intermediary between Martine and Kemp. All three are arrested and eventually plead guilty after Kemp agrees to testify. No innocent persons were falsely accused - the investigation correctly identified all perpetrators from the start.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-sentence during final testimony.
summary: Lois Ryder is murdered in an apparent mugging. Detectives investigate husband Jonathan Ryder, who tries to frame the murder as the work of a serial mugger. Dr. Joel Friedman (Lois's lover) is initially suspected. Henry Willard, a mugger, is arrested after pawning Lois's jewelry but claims he found it in a dumpster. Evidence suggests Jonathan Ryder killed his wife and planted evidence to frame the mugger. Transcript ends mid-trial during Friedman's testimony about identifying the pin Lois was wearing.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Jaime Maser, age 15, shoots and kills his friend Robbie Fenwick with his father's .357 Magnum in what he claims is an accidental shooting during a 'trust' game. Investigation reveals a prior sealed juvenile shooting of Graham Campbell two years earlier with identical circumstances. Jaime is tried as an adult, initially acquitted by reason of mental defect (claiming Tracon intoxication), but then convicted of murder in the second degree for the Campbell shooting after the sealed record is opened and his mother testifies he threatened her with a gun saying 'Graham didn't believe me either.' No falsely accused persons identified in this episode.

source_notes: Serial killer case; multiple victims murdered before episode begins; focus on prosecuting Albert Cheney for Judy Bream murder
summary: Detectives investigate the murder of Judy Bream, strangled in her apartment. They connect her death to two prior murders and identify Albert Cheney, a bookkeeper with access to victims' information through doctors' files and a prior conviction for a similar killing. Cheney is arrested and tried. His wife initially provides a false alibi but later testifies against him after being charged as an accessory. No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies the perpetrator from the start.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: A teenage girl at a Catholic rehab facility accuses a nun of sexual molestation. Investigation reveals the nun was innocent and the girl fabricated the story to discredit the nun. The real perpetrator was the male Executive Director who had been sexually exploiting vulnerable teenage girls at the facility. Sister Bettina was publicly accused, investigated, and arrested before being cleared when the truth emerged.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through the sting operation setup at end
summary: A baby (Henry Ward) freezes to death in an unheated apartment. His mother Jackie Ward is initially accused and arrested, but investigation reveals the building superintendent (Tirado) and enforcer (Turner) intentionally shut off heat to harass tenants on behalf of landlord Iris Corman. Jackie is cleared; Turner is convicted but gets mistrial; prosecutors pursue Corman. Jackie Ward was publicly accused, arrested, and held at Central Booking before being cleared when the true perpetrators were identified.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through closing arguments
summary: Ezra Shore, a Jewish diamond dealer, is beaten and burned. Initial investigation focuses on four Black teenagers (Fontaine Robinson, Cyrus Tanner, Harley Monks, and Reginald Beggs) based on witness statements and Reggie's claim he saw his friends commit the murder. The teens are arrested and indicted, but Reggie recants on the stand, admitting he lied for 'juice' (street credibility). The case is withdrawn from the grand jury. Later investigation reveals Ezra's brother Isaac was laundering money for Joseph Tashjian, who actually killed Ezra when he threatened to expose the operation. Three innocent teens were publicly arrested, perp-walked, and indicted for a murder they didn't commit.

source_notes: Complete transcript provided
summary: Tim Chong, a 17-year-old star physics student, is murdered. Police initially pursue gang-related theories due to his former White Tigers affiliation. Ron Borland is first arrested when his gun is matched to the murder weapon, but is later cleared when detectives discover his wife Marian and son Randy were the actual killers, motivated by academic competition between Tim and Carl Borland for a prestigious science prize. Ron Borland appears to have planted evidence on himself to protect his family.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom testimony scene
summary: Councilman James Vogel is murdered after being blackmailed over his sexual orientation. The investigation reveals Harold Dwyer (a prisoner) and attorney Peter Colson ran a blackmail scheme targeting multiple gay men through prison pen-pal correspondence. While other victims (George Harris, Jay Lingard) were blackmailed, none appear to have suffered public exposure or material harm beyond paying the blackmail. The case centers on the actual perpetrators (Dwyer/Colson) rather than falsely accused parties. Edward Vogel (the victim's father) knew about the blackmail and paid it to keep his son's sexuality secret, but this doesn't qualify him as falsely accused of a crime.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Marshall McFadden, a wealthy takeover specialist, is murdered. Simon Vilanis, a terminally ill former factory worker who lost his job, health insurance, and pension after McFadden's takeover, becomes the primary suspect when his stolen gun is identified as the murder weapon. He is arrested and charged. Investigation reveals the real killers were union enforcer Joey Palmieri (hired by his cousin Eddie Palmieri) at the direction of banker Dwight Corcoran, who paid $100,000 through McFadden's charity foundation to prevent McFadden from testifying about bank fraud. Vilanis is cleared.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through resolution.
summary: Photographer Julian Decker is murdered. Angela Brant, a model who worked as a prostitute through Decker, is accused and prosecuted for murder. Evidence includes her DNA matching vaginal secretions in victim's pajamas, her prints on murder weapon, lies about alibi. She nearly pleads guilty to protect her daughter. Eventually revealed that her 15-year-old daughter Tracy killed Decker after sexual relationship, and Angela attempted to take the blame. Angela is cleared and charges dismissed when father's testimony establishes her alibi.

source_notes: Complex conspiracy case involving assassination of activist Marcus Tate. Multiple suspects accused and cleared.
summary: Marcus Tate, leader of African-American Congress, is assassinated. Mitchell Koblin arrested based on eyewitness testimony and gun possession. Trial reveals weak ballistics evidence and racial tensions. Koblin acquitted on murder but convicted on weapons charge. Post-trial investigation suggests possible conspiracy involving AAC insiders Roland Books and Otis Cook, but insufficient evidence for prosecution.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through closing arguments
summary: Beth Milgram is murdered after breaking up with boyfriend Tommy Beltran. Detectives initially investigate her father Curtis Milgram due to a violent past and insurance policy, but he has an alibi (speeding ticket 80 miles away). Tommy Beltran confesses and is prosecuted for murder two. Defense argues diminished capacity/crime of passion. No innocent persons were publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom scene. Focus is on corporate liability for defective pacemakers causing deaths.
summary: Roberto Martinez, 18, dies when his pacemaker fails. Investigation reveals the device had corroded leads from a defective shipment. Initially Dr. Trevor Hellems is accused of unnecessary surgery and implanting a used pacemaker. Later, Jeffrey Suiter (who recycled/resold pacemakers with altered expiration dates) is arrested for murder. Both are eventually cleared or charges dismissed when evidence shows the real culprit was BioNorm Industries knowingly using defective components. The corporation used Steven Cleary (low-level technician) as a shield from liability.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-sentence at the end.
summary: Investigation into murders of two Mexican teenagers (María and Eduardo Carranza) and inspector Ira Bender who were killed by Rudy Armandariz and Ellis/Betty Drake. The teenagers were enslaved in a sweatshop, handcuffed to beds. No innocent persons were publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies the perpetrators (Rudy Armandariz and the Drakes) from early on. The case focuses on proving their guilt, not on clearing innocent suspects.

source_notes: Episode focuses on Dr. Alex Merritt, a gynecologist who sexually assaults patients under the guise of medical examinations. Multiple victims identified; main prosecution involves police psychologist Dr. Elizabeth Olivet.
summary: Dr. Alex Merritt is accused of sexually assaulting multiple female patients during gynecological examinations. The episode follows the prosecution of Merritt for raping Dr. Elizabeth Olivet, a police psychologist who deliberately returned to his office to gather evidence after hearing complaints from her patient Diane Perkins. Though initially convicted by a jury, the judge dismisses the verdict claiming entrapment. Merritt is later re-arrested after his nurse testifies and additional victims come forward. No false suspects are identified in this episode—the focus is entirely on prosecuting the actual perpetrator.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-sentence at end. Full trial outcome and verdict unclear.
summary: George Costas, a jewelry store owner, shoots and kills brothers Garland and Cecil Booker during an attempted robbery. While Costas claims self-defense, evidence suggests he executed Garland Booker outside the store after the initial confrontation. The brothers were the actual perpetrators attempting robbery, so no innocent persons were falsely accused. Costas is the defendant claiming justifiable homicide. The transcript ends mid-trial, making final disposition unclear.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through final scene showing aftermath of Christobal killing Gaitan.
summary: Manuel Ortega and his wife are murdered at a restaurant. Investigation reveals Manuel worked as a travel agent booking flights for Colombian drug cartel members and hit men. Evidence suggests Manuel killed dealer Felix Arias (who harassed his wife), and the cartel sent hit man Javier Gaitan as retaliation. Gaitan is arrested, tried, and convicted of both murders. At his sentencing, victim's father Juan Christobal shoots Gaitan dead in the courtroom. Initially presented as grieving father, Christobal is later revealed to be a cartel operative who killed Gaitan to prevent him from cooperating with authorities. No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies Gaitan as the restaurant shooter, and all other suspects (Manuel, Ramon) are actually guilty of their accused crimes.

source_notes: Transcript shows Tommy Duff was accused/investigated as a possible mob associate and womanizer, but the episode reveals he was actually a victim of a contract killing disguised as self-defense.
summary: Tommy Duff is murdered on the street. Mary Kostrinski claims self-defense against attempted rape, but investigation reveals she was paid $30,000 by mob boss Jimmy Scanlon to kill Duff, who had been stealing from Scanlon. Kostrinski used a false rape claim and feminist defense to cover a contract killing. While Duff was initially investigated as a suspect in various mob activities, he was the victim, not falsely accused. No qualifying persons for the dataset.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-testimony. Final sections missing.
summary: Nigerian woman Kelani Amoda dies of heroin overdose after drug-filled condom ruptures during smuggling operation. Investigation reveals Chief Nwaka orchestrated smuggling ring using Nigerian immigrants. Philip Marietta (employer) initially accused but later becomes cooperating witness. Babatunde Amoda (Kelani's husband) publicly confronted as possible conspirator but proven innocent. Fabian Ayinde (janitor/swallower) accused, arrested, then deported before trial. Transcript ends mid-trial with defense witness testifying.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial verdict and closing scene.
summary: Seven-year-old Samantha Silver disappears from a department store. Investigation initially focuses on Harold Zorn, a stock clerk with a prior sex abuse conviction, before discovering the girl was taken by her mother's allies who claim the father molested her. Gary Silver is accused of sexually abusing his daughter, publicly tried, and acquitted. The case involves coached testimony, disputed medical evidence, and a mother who wanted to flee the country. A former stock clerk with a sex abuse record is also publicly accused before being cleared.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-dialogue at end
summary: Barbara Spiegelman, 61, is murdered. Her boyfriend Stephen Gregg is arrested, fingerprints found on knives in drawer. He pleads guilty to manslaughter (7-21 years) via plea deal with attorney Sally Knight. Post-plea, prosecutors discover Gregg's allocution contradicts forensics (he said victim was seated; ME says standing). Investigation reveals Kevin Doyle, Barbara's estate attorney, had stronger motive ($500K executor commission, $400K IRS debt). Doyle's fingerprints found at scene, his alibi false. Gregg's charges withdrawn; Doyle arrested and tried. Transcript ends mid-cross-examination, suggesting potential conspiracy between Doyle and Knight to frame/railroad Gregg. Gregg accepted plea despite innocence, likely coerced by incompetent/unethical counsel.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial and plea negotiation scenes.
summary: David Steinmetz confesses to assisting his wife Ursula's suicide via sleeping pills, then admits he smothered her with a pillow when the pills didn't work fast enough. Investigation reveals he may actually be Jacub Skulman, a Jewish ghetto policeman wanted for war crimes in Poland. His wife discovered his true identity before her death. He ultimately pleads guilty to Murder Two to protect his daughter from perjury charges and to seal the trial record. No innocent persons were falsely accused in this episode—Steinmetz was guilty of murdering his wife throughout.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through sentencing hearing
summary: Dan Garrett murders his girlfriend Jennifer Gorham after his psychiatrist Dr. Diane Meade engages in a sexual relationship with him and allegedly manipulates him into eliminating Jennifer as a threat. Both are ultimately convicted - Meade for criminally negligent homicide, Garrett for manslaughter. No innocent persons are accused; both defendants are guilty of their respective crimes.

source_notes: Transcript shows police initially suspect Jonas Stark (nicknamed 'Skate') of murdering Dawn Bryan, a drug addict. Evidence (gun prints, motive) points to Stark. However, investigation reveals Dawn's mother Virginia Bryan actually killed her daughter (mercy killing at Dawn's request). Father Fred Bryan planted the murder weapon to frame Stark.
summary: Jonas Stark was falsely accused of murdering Dawn Bryan. He was arrested twice, subjected to interrogation, had a line-up conducted, and faced $500,000 bail for murder charges. His prints were on the gun clip because he had given the gun to Dawn for protection. The actual killer was Dawn's mother Virginia Bryan (mercy killing). Dawn's father Fred Bryan planted evidence in a sewer pipe to frame Stark. Grand jury ultimately indicted Virginia Bryan only for weapons possession (misdemeanor), not manslaughter.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through closing arguments.
summary: Lt. Janet Hagen is found dead in a hotel room after a Navy party. Ensign Walters confesses to accidentally killing her during a drunken encounter and is convicted by military court-martial. Detectives discover forensic evidence proving Hagen's fatal injury occurred 20+ minutes before Walters touched her. They identify Captain Bunker as the actual killer—Bunker had a history with Hagen from the Naval Academy where she filed a harassment complaint that derailed his career. Walters is proven innocent; Bunker is arrested and tried for murder.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: Dr. Fay Walsh, a research scientist, is murdered in her university lab. Initially, animal rights activist Dirk Chesney is suspected due to threats and past radical actions. Later, evidence points to Professor Donald Walsh (victim's husband) and administrator Susan Boyd in a conspiracy. Walsh is tried and acquitted after Boyd's testimony falls apart on the stand. Eventually revealed that Boyd suffers from erotomania - a delusional belief she was having an affair with Walsh - and she alone murdered Fay Walsh to remove the 'obstacle' to her fantasy relationship.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom testimony
summary: A computer virus inserted into Hogan-Hayes Clinic's blood analyzer causes insulin overdoses, killing 2 patients and putting 3+ in comas. Police initially suspect nurse Rodriguez (who was alone with patients briefly), then hacker John Cook. Cook's father Robert had sued Dr. Hogan for malpractice (diabetic retinopathy), suggesting motive. Evidence against John Cook excluded due to illegal search; prosecutors pivot to charging father Robert Cook with conspiracy, hoping son will confess to save father.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Nicolas Iliescu, a furniture store owner, is murdered. Investigation reveals a credit card fraud scheme. His employee Tommy Zanescu and brother Alex Iliescu are accused. Tommy is accused of murder but has alibi; he and accomplice found murder weapon/car. Alex is arrested for murder but case dismissed on evidence suppression. Alex is then murdered by his son Leon, who confesses. Karen Iliescu initially confesses to protect Leon. Tommy and initially two punk rockers (Wayne Jeffers and accomplice) face false murder accusations with public exposure.

source_notes: Episode centers on Officer Rick Newhouse, a gay cop shot and killed during a drug bust when backup deliberately delayed responding.
summary: Officer Rick Newhouse, a closeted gay police officer, is killed during a confrontation with drug dealers when fellow officers deliberately delayed backup due to anti-gay bias. The prosecution charges three officers with murder two but all are acquitted despite evidence of intentional delay. A dealer (Lucho Martinez) was initially arrested for the murder but the case reveals the real cause was police homophobia. Officer Craig McGraw, also gay and Newhouse's partner, feared for his own safety.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Kathy McKenna, a deaf university student, is murdered. Initially, her ex-boyfriend Paul Crandall is accused, arrested, and publicly charged based on threatening phone transcripts. After linguistic analysis reveals a hearing person wrote the threats, investigation shifts to Kathy's mentor Dr. Gordon Bryce, who killed her when she planned to leave for California. Crandall was publicly arrested and charged before being cleared.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial testimony. Rick Mason trial still in progress at end.
summary: Rick Mason, host of tabloid TV show 'Final Confession,' arranges on-air confrontation between child molester Dr. Joseph Vinton and victim Scott Fisher. Scott's estranged father Sid Fisher shows up and shoots Vinton dead on live TV. Investigation reveals Mason manipulated Scott into calling his father with the location, anticipating violent confrontation for ratings. Mason is prosecuted for manslaughter and facilitation. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode - Sid Fisher committed the murder he's charged with, and Rick Mason is the actual target of the prosecution who allegedly facilitated it.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated at end during defense closing argument.
summary: Roland Kirk, a homeless man with mental illness and crack addiction, is beaten nearly to death with rebar in an alley. Initial suspects include George Siddell (red hat homeless man) and Dr. Creighton (dentist who administered CPR). Investigation reveals Harold Morrissey beat Kirk in retaliation for mugging his wife earlier that evening. Both Siddell and Creighton were innocent of the attack but were publicly suspected/investigated.

summary: Julia Wood, a 19-year-old college student, accuses rock star C-Square (Clarence Carmichael) of rape after going to his hotel suite. The case proceeds to trial where C-Square is convicted of rape in the first degree. No innocent persons were publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode. The defendant was found guilty of the crime he was accused of committing.

No innocent persons are publicly accused; the investigation correctly identifies the perpetrator. Tunney is granted bail despite prosecution objections.

summary: Jonathan Keyes dies in his penthouse. After investigation, his wife Danielle is arrested and convicted of murdering him via insulin overdose. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly harmed - the investigation correctly identifies the killer (Danielle Keyes). The housekeeper Helga and girlfriend Cathy Rogers provide testimony but are never accused themselves. Lance Keyes (the son) hires a PI to find evidence against his stepmother, but is not himself accused. Transcript ends mid-appeal argument, but conviction stands.

summary: Frank McKinnon, a building superintendent, is found dead with head trauma in what initially appears to be a burglary gone wrong. Investigation reveals his son Sean killed him and staged a break-in. The defense claims Frank was abusive and Sean acted in self-defense, but evidence shows Sean was actually the abuser—repeatedly beating his father and controlling the family. Sean's sister Maureen testifies against him about the pattern of abuse, while mother Catherine supports Sean's false narrative. No innocent persons were falsely accused with public exposure or material harm.

summary: A car bomb in a Wall Street garage kills one person. Detectives initially suspect Assad Asalam, an Egyptian diplomat whose leased Mercedes was used in the bombing. He is questioned but has an alibi with State Department officials and reports the car stolen. The victim is identified as Wendy Berman, a 19-year-old runaway involved with Daniel Hendricks' Acherusian Temple cult. Hendricks is ultimately charged with felony murder based on kidnapping (through brainwashing), but the initial suspect Asalam was publicly accused and cleared.

summary: Phillip Swann was convicted 8 years ago of murdering Sidney Cohen based on accomplice Russell Bobbitt's testimony. When Cohen's body is found in a different location than Bobbitt testified, Swann gets a new trial, represents himself, and is acquitted. The episode focuses on Swann's guilt and his manipulation of the system, not on innocent people harmed by false accusations. While some witnesses invested with Swann and lost money, they were not accused of crimes. The only person who might qualify is Russell Bobbitt (the accomplice witness), but his fate is unclear at transcript end and he was likely complicit in some capacity given the evidence. No qualifying innocent persons harmed by false accusations are present in this episode.

Chris is tried as an adult; defense argues XYY chromosome syndrome made him genetically predisposed to violence. No false accusations or wrongly accused persons identified in this episode - the actual perpetrator (Chris) is identified early and remains the defendant throughout.

summary: William Cooper, 56, owner of a meat distribution business, is shot to death in his office. Investigation reveals his wife Irina (26, Russian mail-order bride) was having an affair with Alex Nunez, a lab technician. Evidence shows Nunez killed Cooper after Irina arranged for her husband to be alone at the office. Both are arrested and tried. The case involves a coerced abortion, Cooper's controlling behavior toward Irina, and her desire to bring her son from Russia. No innocent persons were publicly accused or harmed by false accusations - the investigation correctly identified the perpetrators from the start.

Maria becomes a key witness against Laura, who is arrested for murder. The case reveals Maria was wrongly accused of burglary and faced deportation, while Laura is ultimately tried for depraved indifference homicide.

summary: Jason Bregman stages his own kidnapping with accomplices Watson and Navarro to extort $4 million from his father Sol. No innocent persons are falsely accused - Jason was complicit, and Watson/Navarro are guilty of the crimes charged (larceny, though acquitted of attempted murder). The case involves a spoiled son exploiting his wealthy father, not false accusations against innocent parties.

summary: Young woman Debra Elkins gives birth and claims her baby was stolen. Investigation reveals she promised the baby to multiple couples for money. Dorothy Baxter, a desperate infertile woman who believed she had a contract for the baby, kidnaps the infant from the hospital. Baxter is arrested but ultimately receives a suspended sentence. The episode focuses on private adoption fraud, with Baxter being the primary falsely accused party who suffers public arrest and prosecution despite being portrayed sympathetically as a victim of Elkins' scheme.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete. Episode focuses on Judge Joel Thayer stalking/threatening Janet Rudman and her child, then falsely accusing ADA Claire Kincaid of misconduct when she investigates.
summary: Judge Joel Thayer stalks Janet Rudman and threatens her child after their affair. When ADA Claire Kincaid investigates, Thayer retaliates by falsely claiming she made sexual advances toward him, resulting in her professional censure. Kincaid is later vindicated when evidence proves Thayer's guilt.

source_notes: Episode centers on accidental shooting of Angel Ramirez by Kevin Parker, who was trying to shoot gun dealer Juan Domingo. Multiple false suspects before the truth emerges.
summary: 14-year-old Angel Ramirez is shot and killed on the street. Initially appears random, but investigation reveals Kevin Parker (16) shot at gun dealer Juan Domingo (who had shot Parker's friend Ricky Morales) and accidentally hit Angel. Juan Domingo is falsely accused of Angel's murder before evidence points to Parker. Multiple students are questioned, Billy Wojak is arrested for holding guns in his locker. Case ends in mistrial after key witness Domingo is killed in suspicious circumstances.

summary: Florence Manning is killed by a mail bomb. Her estranged husband, physicist Edward Manning, is initially suspected due to divorce proceedings and his new girlfriend. Max Weiss, a struggling physicist, is arrested after bomb materials are found in his lab drawer. Weiss initially claims Manning hired him, but prosecutors discover Weiss had his own motive: Manning stole his scientific theory and sabotaged his grant application. The case reveals Weiss targeted Manning but accidentally killed Manning's estranged wife at their old shared address. Manning is also investigated for scientific theft/larceny but appears to avoid full cooperation to protect his reputation.

summary: Episode involves multiple murders on a single day. Ken Scofield is shot in Battery Park; Drew Washington is killed in a robbery; Scott Hexter becomes primary suspect in Scofield killing based on witness descriptions and parking tickets for tan Chevy in area. Hexter is arrested despite providing alibi (movies) he cannot verify. Evidence shows his car in Forest Park at time of Queens murder AND in Riverdale (hit-and-run) 10 minutes after Battery Park murder - physically impossible. Transcript ends before resolution, but strong implication Hexter may be wrongly accused. Also features Louisa D'Angelo who kills abusive husband (actual perpetrator, not false suspect). No other clearly innocent accused persons identified with sufficient public exposure/harm.

summary: Benny Williams, business manager and father of baseball star Pat Williams, is beaten to death. However, evidence emerges that Pat Williams may have lied about his gambling activity and his whereabouts the night of the murder. The transcript ends abruptly during what appears to be a confrontation with Pat about the truth. Papa Doc appears to be innocent or at least wrongly charged based on developing evidence pointing toward Pat.

source_notes: Episode involves a hit-and-run case (Joshua Berger) and subsequent riot murder (Isaac Roberts). Complex racial tensions and legal maneuvering around both cases.
summary: Joshua Berger, a Jewish businessman, hits and kills 12-year-old Damon Fox in Harlem. Forensic evidence shows he was not speeding (20-25 mph). An eyewitness (Bobby) fabricated testimony claiming Berger was going 50 mph, likely coached by Reverend Ott. Grand jury refuses to indict Berger based on forensic evidence contradicting eyewitness. Berger pleads to leaving the scene. This triggers a riot where Isaac Roberts kills John De Santis (mistaken for Jewish). Roberts is tried for murder but jury deadlocks; DA declines retrial.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom scenes but cuts off mid-sentence at end.
summary: A 10-year-old girl, Wendy Sylvester, goes missing from her foster home. Police discover she was taken by Arnette Fenady, a volunteer poetry teacher who had previously been arrested for attempting to kidnap another child. Fenady believes she is rescuing abused children and confuses them with her own dead daughter, Crystal. The case examines the foster care system's failures and Fenady's mental illness. No innocent parties are falsely accused—Fenady is guilty of kidnapping, and the investigation correctly identifies her as the perpetrator. Wendy ultimately lies on the stand to protect Fenady, whom she sees as having saved her from an abusive situation.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-sentence. Final dialogue cuts off during legal discussion about Korey Burke's diary.
summary: Tennis prodigy Korey Burke is attacked at practice - her wrist broken, ending her season. Initial suspect Alan Lovitz (obsessed fan) is cleared by lineup. Marc Kenner confesses to being hired by rival player Alison Hall for $10k, but recants when his confession is suppressed. Prosecutors then suspect Korey's father Mitchell Burke orchestrated the attack to preserve endorsement money when Korey wanted to quit. Transcript reveals Korey has history of 'accidents' and sees psychiatrist. Final twist suggests Korey may have arranged her own injury to escape her father's pressure. Alison Hall arrested and charged despite weak motive. Transcript ends mid-legal argument about Korey's psychiatric diary as potential exculpatory evidence.

summary: Harry Renkmeyer is found dead, initially appearing to be pushed into traffic by a homeless man named Rudy. Investigation reveals Renkmeyer was shot before being run over. Ann Madsen, CEO of Nature's Way baby food company, is coerced into testifying against her business partner Steven Green after initially lying under oath out of fear of the Russian mob (Gruskov family). Rudy is arrested but later cleared when autopsy shows shooting, not traffic accident. Ann Madsen commits perjury under threat, then is arrested for it to force her cooperation.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom testimony. Episode centers on Dr. Nancy Haas, a non-MD scientist offering alternative cancer treatment with apricot seeds, accused of murdering Ann Bennett by convincing her to forgo surgery.
summary: Ann Bennett dies of liver cancer after following Dr. Nancy Haas's metabolic therapy instead of having surgery. Investigation reveals Haas charged patients $75,000 for treatments using apricot seeds (containing trace cyanide/amygdaline). No innocent suspects are publicly accused; investigation focuses on Haas from early on. Nicholas Bennett is briefly considered but never publicly accused or confronted as a suspect. The case proceeds as a murder prosecution against Haas for fraudulently convincing patients to avoid life-saving surgery.

The investigation shifts to Michael Dobson, Sandra's husband, who is eventually arrested and tried for attempted murder/murder. The transcript appears to cut off during trial proceedings, so the final resolution is unclear.

summary: Japanese businessman Shiunro Hayashi is murdered in his hotel room. Investigation initially focuses on hotel employee Danny Zabel and his brother-in-law Charles Kett (who robbed another hotel guest previously). Zabel is arrested as accomplice but later cleared when Kett has alibi. Singer Suzy is questioned after being with Hayashi but cleared when forensics show different woman's hair. Investigation ultimately leads to Martha Bowen, who killed Hayashi after he forced her into prostitution in Japan a year earlier. Two innocent people publicly accused: Danny Zabel and Suzy.

He is publicly investigated but later cleared when the timeline and evidence point to Steve Martell (Laura's current husband) and potentially Maggie Conner (Laura's daughter). The transcript ends mid-testimony, making full analysis incomplete.

summary: Episode concerns a 1971 armed robbery of Nucon Technologies where Officer Vincent Perella was killed. In present day (1994), the stolen money and murder weapon are recovered from a safe deposit box. Investigation reveals Susan Forrest (living under alias Rita Levitan) was involved. However, Henry Maybrook (security guard) and his cousin Eddie were falsely accused of the vault burglary before the real perpetrators were identified. Professor William Goodwin was also accused but appears to have actually aided Susan Forrest (partial involvement). Transcript cuts off during Margaret Pauley's testimony, making complete analysis difficult.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through final courtroom resolution. Lieutenant Van Buren shoots James Gordon (mentally retarded, unarmed 14-year-old) during attempted ATM robbery. Zack Rowland (accomplice with gun) initially accused, later charged with felony murder.
summary: Lt. Van Buren shoots unarmed, mentally retarded 14-year-old James Gordon during ATM encounter, believing accomplice Zack Rowland had a gun. James dies; Van Buren faces investigation and grand jury. No-billed by grand jury prioritizing public safety over scrutiny of police conduct. Zack charged with felony murder after gun recovered. Episode explores competence to commit crime, prosecutorial withholding of evidence (bracelet motive), and racial dynamics in justice system. James Gordon qualifies as innocent person harmed by false accusation of attempted robbery—he lacked mental capacity to form criminal intent and was buying girlfriend's bracelet with legitimately earned money.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated at the end during plea discussion. Episode centers on Eileen and Martin Willach, whose infant Emily dies. Investigation reveals two prior infant deaths (Daniel, Caroline) and an incident with foster child Gary.
summary: Baby Emily Willach is reported kidnapped from Central Park but is found dead in a cooler by the Hudson River. Investigation reveals Martin Willach faked the kidnapping to cover up the death. Focus shifts to mother Eileen Willach, suspected of smothering Emily and potentially two previous biological children plus harming a foster child. However, a bald man with a camera was witnessed in the park that morning and became an early suspect before being cleared. The case ends in a hung jury (9-3 for conviction) with prosecution seeking retrial.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through defense opening; episode focuses on sexual coercion/quid pro quo harassment rather than traditional rape case
summary: Lyssa Wesley dies in car crash after alleged rape by Councilman Spencer Talbert. Investigation reveals pattern of sexual coercion at his former law firm. Sarah Maslin initially claims rape but recants, revealing quid pro quo sexual harassment (partnership in exchange for sex). Prosecution pivots to larceny by extortion theory. Episode centers on distinguishing forcible rape from coerced consent under threat of career destruction.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial testimony
summary: Lawyer Arthur Kopinsky is murdered. Initial investigation focuses on Carl Piselli, who was publicly accused of the murder and cleared via alibi. John Curren, a Tappan victim, is then arrested and tried. The case reveals Kopinsky was running a scam on Tappan victims while also blackmailing Tappan over hidden money. Tappan manipulated Curren into killing Kopinsky. Both Piselli and initially John Curren qualify as falsely accused persons who suffered public exposure and consequences.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom hearing scene
summary: David Lempert, a city Parks Department accountant, is murdered after serving as a juror in mob boss Vincent Dosso's trial. Investigation reveals Lempert was bribed to hang the jury. Defense attorney Paul Kopell helped facilitate jury tampering by bribing a court clerk to identify vulnerable jurors. Lempert was later killed, likely because he became a liability. The episode focuses on prosecuting Dosso and Kopell for conspiracy to murder. No falsely accused innocent persons are identified in the transcript - Furini and Dosso appear to be the actual perpetrators, and Kopell facilitated the crime. Lempert was a victim who accepted a bribe but was not accused of a crime he didn't commit.

summary: Katie Blanchard, a wealthy heroin addict, is found dead behind a dumpster. Her brother Matthew and family adviser Jerome Kamen are accused at different points. Matthew injected Katie with heroin and called Kamen when she started convulsing. Kamen took her from the apartment but left her to die instead of seeking medical help. Matthew was initially suspected and later testified against Kamen. The transcript cuts off during cross-examination, making final disposition unclear.

summary: Dr. Eileen Reed, an abortion provider, is murdered. Nancy Gunther infiltrates the clinic under a false name to gather information. Randall Jenkins shoots Dr. Reed for revenge after his wife had an abortion. Drew Seeley, a defrocked priest and anti-abortion activist, confesses to orchestrating the murder to put abortion on trial but ultimately admits he couldn't pull the trigger himself. Nancy Gunther's infiltration and information gathering directly enabled the murder, and she was publicly exposed during the investigation and trial. Dr. Simon Reed (the victim's husband) was publicly questioned and suffered emotional harm related to the accusation that he wanted his wife to stop performing abortions (though this is a stretch as he was more a witness than accused).

summary: Wallace Holbrook, a Wall Street executive, is murdered in his home. Initially staged as a suicide, investigation reveals his neck was broken and the shotgun wound was postmortem. Police focus on Bud Greer, Holbrook's top trader, who made $7 million but was actually running phantom trades. Greer is arrested based on fingerprints at the scene and motive (Holbrook discovered the fraud). Defense claims racial bias and introduces 'black rage' defense. No innocent suspects are publicly accused or harmed - Greer appears to be the actual perpetrator throughout the investigation.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through trial and appeal scenes
summary: Two teenage boys, Shane Sutter and Kyle Winters, are arrested and convicted for raping 16-year-old Corey Russell on videotape. The case involves a points-for-sex competition among a clique called the Mack Rangers. The convictions are overturned on appeal due to excluded evidence about the Rangers, leading to a conspiracy case strategy. No individuals are proven or strongly implied innocent after being publicly accused in this episode.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through court proceedings. Episode focuses on fertility fraud investigation.
summary: Episode centers on Dr. Jordan Gilbert, a fertility doctor who commits fraud by using his own sperm for artificial insemination procedures while claiming to use anonymous donors, and by lying to patients about pregnancies. Susan Parker, one of his patients, has a violent breakdown at her husband's workplace (believing he caused her miscarriage), resulting in her death by security guard. Investigation reveals Gilbert's extensive fraud scheme affecting dozens of patients. While Gilbert's actions harm many people through deception, no one is falsely accused of a crime they didn't commit. Brandon Parker is initially suspected of spousal abuse causing the miscarriage, but evidence supports his account of self-defense, and Susan Parker was never actually pregnant (Gilbert's lie). The episode is about medical/financial fraud, not false criminal accusations with public exposure.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through most of final scene but cuts off mid-sentence during negotiation about Stewart Barclay's testimony deal.
summary: William Prescott, an accountant, is shot and killed. Initially suspected is union baggage handler Harrigan over job cuts, then Jimmy Rose (who was acquitted of a prior murder with the same gun). The gun is traced to Colin Harrigan (Tom's son), a expelled prep school student who had threatened another student. Colin is arrested based on gunpowder residue on gloves, but the case is dismissed when the search warrant is suppressed. Tom Harrigan (the father) then confesses to protect his son, but his allocution contains factual errors proving he didn't do it. The actual shooter appears to be Colin Harrigan, with conspiracy involvement by wealthy student Stewart Barclay, whose father (school board chairman/legal counsel) tries to negotiate immunity for his son's testimony.

source_notes: Transcript appears truncated mid-sentence during suppression hearing argument.
summary: A building explosion kills 12-year-old Robbie Cuneo. Police initially suspect general contractor Buzz Palley due to financial motive and lies, then arrest him. Later evidence shifts focus to Hank Chappel (husband of Palley's girlfriend Chris), who had access to explosives and fired warning shots at Palley. Chappel is convicted. Post-conviction, police realize Palley never returned to the scene the night of the bombing, suggesting he set it. New wiretap evidence leads to arrests of both Palley and Chris Chappel, with defense arguing Hank Chappel was wrongfully convicted. Transcript ends mid-suppression hearing.
