summary: Blair Carlson is kidnapped and held in a Harlem building, then dies fleeing into traffic. Ronny Aldridge, who runs Fresh Horizons youth program, is charged with kidnap-murder after failing to get $200k from Pete Gardner (Carlson's boyfriend, a disgraced Wall Street CEO) to buy a farm for his boys. Carlos, a youth in the program, is initially suspected but cleared. Aldridge claims Carlson suggested faking her own kidnapping. Despite strong evidence, jury acquits Aldridge (jury nullification influenced by Gardner's Wall Street greed). No persons shown to be falsely accused meet the innocence + public harm criteria.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through final scene where Martin Garvik reveals the truth about his wife being the actual spy.
summary: Alex Boone, a journalist who spent 6 years in Chinese prison for espionage, is murdered while writing a book about a 1998 espionage case. Police initially suspect David Sutton, son of convicted spy Martin Garvik, of hiring hitman Mike Adams to silence Boone. The case reveals Martin Garvik took the fall for his wife Elyse, who actually passed defense secrets to China before committing suicide. David believed he was protecting his father by having Boone killed, not knowing his mother was the real spy.

source_notes: Transcript provided; episode centers on murder of TV reporter Dawn Prescott investigating fraud; fraud mastermind's wife Irene Matson is the killer.
summary: TV reporter Dawn Prescott is murdered while investigating hedge fund fraud by Frederic Matson. Initially, Matson himself is suspected, then Colombian drug lord Livan Santana (who had motive to silence Prescott). Evidence eventually points to Matson's wife Irene, who confesses. Frederic Matson nearly takes the fall by falsely claiming Santana did it to protect his wife. Joe Delaney, a news anchor, is briefly threatened with murder charges for endangering Prescott by tipping off Matson, but is never formally charged—he loses his job instead. Livan Santana is accused of murdering whistleblower Vince Decker but is not prosecuted (fled to Colombia). The episode shows multiple false paths before reaching the true killer.

source_notes: Complete transcript available
summary: Three white teenagers (Tony Stratton, Timothy Moore, Kyle Chase) attack Hispanic day laborers in a series of hate crimes, including branding victims with a heated Mexican peso. Oswaldo Morales is thrown from their car after being assaulted and branded, left in a coma. Rey Alvarez, an unemployed auto worker from Detroit, is murdered by the same group. All three teens are arrested and prosecuted. Kyle Chase testifies against the other two in exchange for a lighter sentence. The defendants are acquitted of murder but convicted of first-degree assault against Morales. They receive 5-year sentences. After the trial, Morales dies when his mother signs a DNR order, leading to new murder charges. No person in this episode qualifies as falsely accused then proven/strongly implied innocent.

source_notes: Law & Order transcript: murdered firefighter couple, hidden drug money, rookie firefighter Nick Spence wrongly implicated then killed in suspicious warehouse fire
summary: Firefighter Lt. Thomas Cooper and wife Linda are murdered in home invasion. Investigation reveals Cooper found $400K in 40-year-old drug money hidden in walls. Rookie firefighter Nick Spence becomes suspect due to hazing motive and knowledge of money. Spence dies in suspicious warehouse fire before arrest. Later revealed: senior firefighters Brad Toshack, Walters, and McShane committed murders for money; Toshack deliberately sent Spence to death in fire to silence him.

source_notes: Transcript shows two British exchange students murdered; initial suspect Charlie Headlind (bipolar neighbor) died trying to save them; actual killer was Wendy Teal (bipolar woman whose brother withheld her meds); brother Dennis convicted via conspiracy theory after initial depraved indifference case collapsed.
summary: Two British grad students (Colin Tilbrook and Geraldine Sarfield) were murdered and set on fire. Police initially suspected Charlie Headlind, a bipolar neighbor, but he died from smoke inhalation trying to save them. Investigation revealed Wendy Teal (Charlie's girlfriend, also bipolar) killed them during a psychotic episode. Her brother Dennis had withheld her medication for three months to incapacitate her while he stole/sold a family heirloom. The prosecution initially pursued Dennis for depraved indifference murder, then pivoted to conspiracy/felony murder theory when Dennis's own testimony about Wendy being 'rational' undermined the original case. Dennis took a plea for 20-to-life.

source_notes: Transcript analyzed for false accusation patterns
summary: Three homeless men are murdered in a copycat of the 'Boxcar Basher' serial killer. Police initially suspect Jonah Applebaum (the 'Bipolar Roller'), a mentally ill street performer, believing victim Paco was killed because he wore Jonah's skates. Jonah is arrested, publicly exposed, and jailed. Later evidence reveals Jonah's business partners Grant and Bob Carpenter committed the murders to frame Jonah or eliminate him from their failing T-shirt business. Jonah is cleared of these three murders but is subsequently revealed to be the actual Boxcar Basher serial killer (9 prior murders). The partners are prosecuted for the three copycat murders.

source_notes: Transcript shows complex political corruption case involving Governor Shalvoy's wife Rita arranging murder of Charles Whitley to obtain his job at Boland Initiative
summary: Charles Whitley, executive director of Boland Initiative, is murdered. Investigation reveals Rita Shalvoy (Governor's wife) hired Bobby Amato to force Whitley out of his job so she could take it as part of a political deal involving a U.S. Senate seat appointment. Amato made compromising S&M videos of Whitley, then killed him when he wouldn't resign. No falsely accused innocent persons with public exposure - Amato confessed and was actually guilty; investigation targeted the correct perpetrators throughout.

summary: Greg Tanner, a war veteran dealing drugs on campus and suffering PTSD from Abu Ghraib, is shot and killed by Professor Kevin Franklin. Franklin claims self-defense, saying Tanner threatened him. Investigation reveals Tanner witnessed torture sanctioned by Franklin's legal memos and may have been trying to implicate Franklin or seek compensation. Case pivots from self-defense murder trial to prosecution of Franklin and Bush administration officials for conspiracy to commit torture. No falsely accused innocent parties are identified—Franklin is the defendant throughout and claims self-defense rather than innocence of the shooting itself.

Maldonado is arrested, publicly identified in lineup, and held in custody before charges are dropped when Emma's lies unravel. Jim Anderson (Daisy's fiancé) is also falsely suspected of murder and arrested for obstruction before Emma is revealed as the actual killer. Emma also falsely accuses Detective Lupo and Judge Maxen of sexual coercion during trial.

summary: Episode involves two parallel bomb plots targeting synagogues. One plot (led by Charles Cole, Ali Hossam, and Joe Darwish) is entirely orchestrated by police informant Sameer Ahmed with fake explosives. A second, real plot (Arthur Jackson group) uses a police-supplied detonator that was meant for the fake plot. Don Sorenson shoots James Caruso (an innocent dumpster diver) during a virtual kidnapping scheme, believing Caruso was his daughter's kidnapper. Multiple people are falsely accused or entrapped.

summary: Joy Johnson is murdered. Multiple people are accused or investigated: son Tim (autistic, initially confesses), teen D.J. Lovell (took Tim's key), reality show competitor Belinda Alvarez (visited house day of murder). All are later cleared. Larry Johnson (husband) is ultimately charged but trial ends in mistrial. Tim, D.J., and Belinda all experienced public exposure and consequences from accusations before being cleared.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: Dr. Walter Benning, a late-term abortion provider, is murdered during church service. Detectives investigate several suspects including Jonah Leland (boyfriend of patient), Kevin Morton (grandfather of patient's fetus), and ultimately Wayne Grogan, a pro-life protestor who confesses. During investigation, Jonah Leland and Kevin Morton are both publicly accused/questioned but proven innocent. Morton was publicly confronted at his workplace (university) and interrogated regarding the murder. Jonah was also publicly questioned at his workplace in front of his boss.

source_notes: Transcript shows Sid Maxwell/Todd Bissell murdered by Kerry Sands (insane); several people from FlashPosse website prosecuted for manslaughter. Detective Bernard publicly exposed for child support issues during trial.
summary: Sid Maxwell is found dead in apparent autoerotic asphyxiation. Investigation reveals he was murdered by Kerry Sands, a schizophrenic woman incited by the FlashPosse website that posted his address, building codes, and threats. During prosecution of website operators, defense attorney publicly exposes Detective Bernard's past child support failures using internet-sourced information, humiliating him in court. Bernard's personal life becomes evidence to attack his credibility.

source_notes: Transcript shows investigation of Nina Wilshere murder by Mexican cartel-trained child assassins. Focus on Rafael Alvarez's prosecution and cooperation.
summary: Nina Wilshere is murdered by cartel-trained teenage assassins. Investigation initially focuses on chiropractor Lucas Evra, who owed money and had confrontation with victim. He is cleared when police discover Nina was a marijuana dealer targeted by rival cartel. Episode examines prosecution of juvenile killers and witness intimidation.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Brenda Sawyer is accused of drunk driving after a fatal crash killing 7 people (including 3 children). Public and family believe she was intoxicated (.09 BAC, grain alcohol bottle found). Later proven she was drugged with Propofol by coworker Zach Marshall, who wanted to discredit her whistleblowing about Lextenda (a cancer drug). Marshall intended a minor accident/DWI to ruin her credibility with FDA, but it resulted in mass fatalities. Brenda suffered extreme public vilification, family accusations, media coverage, and died from injuries - all while innocent of drunk driving.

source_notes: Complex episode involving defense attorney Marcus Woll conspiring to murder witnesses across multiple cases spanning 5 years
summary: Defense attorney Marcus Woll (former ADA) systematically murders or arranges murders of witnesses who threaten his cases. Henry Lovett, a pharmacist who could have cleared Alvin 'Mad Dog' Jackson of murder, was killed after Woll obtained his location. Maggie Hayes was murdered before testifying against Woll's client William Avery. Jackson was wrongfully convicted and served 5+ years. The episode also features failed attempt to kill witness Paige Regan.

source_notes: Three men enter Stan Harkavy's tax office for what appears to be a robbery. Stan shoots all three with his shotgun, killing two. Investigation reveals the 'robbery' was actually a shakedown orchestrated by Max Purcell to intimidate Stan into selling his building. Stan recognized one of the men (Duane Jefferson) from an earlier encounter but lied about it, suggesting he knew it wasn't a real robbery when he opened fire.
summary: This episode contains NO qualifying innocent people who suffered harm from false accusations. While Max Purcell was accused and charged, he was actually guilty of orchestrating the shakedown. Stan Harkavy killed two men who were not actually planning to rob him (it was intimidation), but the men themselves were willing participants in the criminal scheme and were not falsely accused. The episode explores Stan's potential guilt for an unjustified shooting, but no innocent person was harmed by false accusations.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Community organizer James Landy is murdered and initially believed to be a federal employee. Investigation reveals he was secretly videotaping Rights Alliance colleagues to expose potential extortion. Multiple suspects emerge: Jerry Ganz (Patriot Ranger who threatened Landy), Marissa Rumstead and Arturo Ramirez (Rights Alliance employees who disposed of evidence), and ultimately Courtney Owens and Davis Webb (who ordered the killing to prevent exposure of their affair and embezzlement cover-up). Jerry Ganz is arrested, jailed, and publicly protested over before being cleared as the killer.

source_notes: Transcript shows a blackmail scheme involving journalist Megan Kerik's research on Vanessa Carville's relationships with female employees. Multiple people accused during investigation.
summary: Journalist Megan Kerik is murdered while researching an exposé about TV personality Vanessa Carville's sexual relationships with female employees. Initial investigation focuses on Carville as a suspect due to motive to silence Kerik. Editor Dennis Di Palma is later revealed to have hijacked Kerik's research for blackmail, then arrested for extortion. Di Palma is initially suspected of murder before evidence points to his accomplice Derek Fanning. The case involves false accusations against Carville and temporary suspicion of Di Palma for murder before the real killer is identified.

source_notes: Triple homicide case involving Justin Sachs and Amanda Evans (aka Bonnie). Amanda claims amnesia and is found legally insane, then testifies against Justin.
summary: Justin Sachs and Amanda Evans (going by 'Bonnie') murder the Morgan family (5 victims). Amanda is found legally insane and pleads NGRI. She testifies against Justin, who is convicted. No innocent persons are wrongfully accused in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies the perpetrators from the start. Detective Lupes' past PTSD issues are revealed during cross-examination but are not related to a false accusation in this case.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Cesar Ramirez, a 16-year-old charter school student, is murdered by being set on fire. Investigation initially focuses on jealousy and school rivalries. Abel Dolan and three friends from Aaron Burr High School are eventually revealed as the killers. The case involves false alibis provided by Principal Woodside, a gang-rape of witness Jolie Henderson to silence her, and Moses Dolan (Abel's brother) initially providing then retracting a tip about evidence. Jolie Henderson emerges as a key false suspect who suffered severe consequences including gang-rape as retaliation for potential testimony.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Justine Stebbins, a physical therapy student moonlighting as an escort, is murdered in a NYC hotel. Lab tech Robby Vickery, who dated her, is initially arrested. He's later cleared when evidence points to grad student Alex Conway, who was robbing escorts to fund gambling. Vickery was publicly arrested at work and interrogated before being cleared.

source_notes: Transcript shows complex case with Innocence Coalition challenge to conviction; main defendant Cedric Stuber ultimately pleads guilty to man one (25 years). Multiple layers including witness credibility issues, potential alternative suspect Jon Sorrentino, and prosecutor Mike Cutter's license controversy.
summary: Cedric Stuber is arrested and convicted for a gay-bashing murder based on eyewitness ID. The Innocence Coalition challenges the conviction with new evidence suggesting the victim's husband Jon Sorrentino may have arranged the killing. Investigation reveals the Coalition's witness (drug dealer Rodrigo Diaz) was likely lying in retaliation. Stuber is ultimately not innocent but Jon Sorrentino was also falsely accused of hiring a hit man during the investigation. The episode explores themes of wrongful accusation, prosecutorial conduct, and the complexity of determining innocence.

source_notes: Four police officers shot in pizzeria; shooter Calvin Stokes arrested. Investigation reveals Officers Ramos and Colson were running an informant operation, pressuring Stokes.
summary: Calvin Stokes kills four police officers. During investigation, detectives briefly suspect and publicly question an innocent man who had stolen a BMW near the crime scene. The suspect is brought in for lineup, interrogated, tested for gunshot residue, and witnesses (including a widow of one of the victims) are brought to identify him before he is cleared. This public process occurs in front of multiple officers and the widow.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom testimony
summary: Dr. Oscar Silva is poisoned at a climate symposium. Initially, Dr. Everett Brown is suspected due to stolen emails showing data manipulation and Brown's statement against cap-and-trade that benefited Silva financially. Investigation reveals Silva's ex-wife Dana and her father Nelson Lehman as the true conspirators, with Dana's current husband Phillip Shoemaker also involved. Brown was publicly accused and threatened despite being innocent.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Brenna Lane is murdered after trying to expose her brother Dustin's inappropriate relationship with Senator Peterson's wife, Camille. Initially, police suspect Dustin of killing Brenna out of jealousy/obsession. Evidence is gathered via a terrorism-justified search warrant (later suppressed). Andrea Wheaton, the senator's chief of staff, is arrested for the murder after cat hair from the crime scene is found in a rental car she procured. Andrea falsely confesses to an affair with Dustin to protect Camille Peterson. Eventually, Camille confesses to killing Brenna to prevent her from exposing the affair and destroying her relationship with Dustin. Andrea served as an accessory after the fact, cleaning up the crime scene and planting evidence in Dustin's apartment to frame him.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through courtroom scenes and final dialogue.
summary: Randy Colwyn is initially accused of murdering his cousin Annie Douglas via heroin overdose to benefit from inheritance; he is later proven to have supplied drugs but not murdered her. Catherine Douglas, Bruce Graham, Dr. Balicheck, Roger Weil, and Louise Casey are arrested for murder conspiracy related to deaths timed for 2010 estate tax avoidance. Charges against Casey and Weil are dismissed; Dr. Balicheck is revealed as an unwitting participant and charges dropped. The episode focuses on proving Catherine Douglas orchestrated her father's death through accountant Graham and Dr. Balicheck's clinic.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete with full courtroom scenes and resolution
summary: Jerome Turner is murdered by his cousin Michael Reed over a dispute about cooperating with Hema Labs regarding DNA testing of Jerome's son Jaden. While Joseph Hernandez (the PI hired by Hema) is investigated as a suspect, the evidence shows Michael Reed committed the murder out of anger that Jerome was accepting payment from the company that had exploited their family for decades. No one is proven or strongly implied innocent - Michael Reed is the actual perpetrator, and Hernandez, while morally culpable for his tactics, did not commit the murder. The case resolves with a plea deal and settlement for the Robinson family.

summary: David Di Napoli is murdered in his home, stabbed in a dog cage. Wife Marielle is initially suspected and arrested. She's publicly accused, tried in media coverage, and eventually exonerated when evidence points to Josh Felner, who murdered David to protect an asset-hiding divorce scheme. Marielle suffered arrest, public exposure, trial preparation before charges dismissed. Episode also involves wrongful suspicion of Marty Ashcroft briefly.

source_notes: Transcript shows detectives investigating a credible school shooting/bombing threat from a blogger called 'Moot.' Investigation leads to identifying Rick Benson, a teacher who was falsely accused of molesting a student.
summary: Rick Benson, a 9th grade English teacher with only 3 years experience, was accused of molesting a student after the student urinated in a classroom trashcan and Benson tried to stop him. The accusation was fabricated. Benson spent 8 months in a 'rubber room' (Temporary Reassignment Center) during proceedings. The complaint was eventually dismissed, but the Department of Education told him he'd never get tenure, effectively ending his teaching career. His girlfriend left him during the accusations. The experience drove him to plan a school shooting/bombing, which was thwarted by police before any deaths occurred.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete through closing arguments. Episode focuses on Nicole Bell shooting Henry King, a celebrity accused of 40+ rapes who was released after appellate court vacated conviction due to prosecutor's immunity promise.
summary: Henry King, a celebrity released from prison after rape conviction was overturned, is murdered. Nicole Bell, one of his rape victims, is arrested and confesses to the killing. The episode centers on whether her actions constitute murder or justifiable homicide. No innocent people are falsely accused in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies Nicole Bell as the shooter, and she confesses. The moral/legal conflict is whether a rape victim killing her rapist should be prosecuted, not whether an innocent person was wrongly accused.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Kyle Morrison is murdered in Central Park. Nina Ellis, his fiancée and CEO of Hythena (a medical testing company), is arrested and tried for his murder. During trial, Nina claims she was a victim of domestic abuse by Kyle and killed him in self-defense. The prosecution proves Nina fabricated the abuse claims - her broken arm came from falling off a horse during polo practice, not from Kyle's violence. Derek Seaver, the former CTO who was initially suspected and nearly framed by Nina, is proven innocent when investigators discover Nina called in a false tip to implicate him.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Amanda Larson, a social media influencer, goes missing in NYC. Joseph Denzig is initially arrested as detectives find Amanda's driver's license in his closet and his blood at the crime scene. He's publicly arrested and accused of involvement but is later cleared when he explains he was burglarizing her van and witnessed someone else abduct Amanda. The real perpetrator, Daniel Garrett, is subsequently identified and convicted. Denzig faces arrest, interrogation, and public exposure for crimes he didn't commit (kidnapping/murder), though he did commit burglary.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Judge David Keating is murdered in a parking garage. Investigation reveals Lucy McDaniel, a world-class tennis player, killed him after he refused to allow her to marry her boyfriend. The case exposes that Lucy was under an exploitative guardianship controlled by her father and the judge. Greg Wallace and Jesse Weisman ('Dr. Weisman') were initially suspected but cleared. Wallace was publicly confronted and investigated; Weisman was present at the crime scene and threatened the judge but had been paid. Both experienced consequences from being falsely suspected.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: Derek Hoyt, a family man planning to run for Congress, is pushed in front of a bus and killed. The murder is committed by Manny Lopez, a follower of right-wing media mogul Jordan Reed. Reed had orchestrated a smear campaign against Hoyt, posting fake photos depicting him as a pedophile and posting inflammatory lies to incite his followers. Lopez believed the lies and killed Hoyt thinking he was protecting children. Reed is ultimately convicted of Murder Two under a depraved indifference theory. While multiple people were accused during the investigation (the business rival, etc.), none were publicly exposed or materially harmed by false accusations - they were quickly cleared through standard questioning. The case centers on incitement to violence rather than wrongful accusation.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Head of School Henry Gleason is murdered at Davenport prep school. Cooper Young, a scholarship student, becomes initial suspect after being found running from scene with blood on jacket. He is publicly arrested and held before his lawyer intervenes. Cooper is later proven innocent when evidence reveals Bennett Richardson brought gun to school and accidentally shot Gleason while targeting Cooper. The prosecution ultimately charges both Bennett and his father John Richardson, who provided the gun and encouraged confrontation.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Alexis Morphew, CFO of QuestArc, is strangled to death. Multiple suspects are publicly investigated: Terry Bellantoni (ex-CFO with anger issues and threatening emails), Robert Fletcher (journalist initially suspected of affair), Gus Imelski (solar company founder who lost $250M deal), and Colin Baker (consultant who made fatal error). All are exposed through police investigation before Baker is tried and acquitted by reason of insanity (Havana Syndrome defense). Bellantoni, Fletcher, and Imelski are cleared; all experience public exposure and harm from the accusation process.

source_notes: Episode focuses on the murder of Mary Costello (living as Ella Whitlock) and subsequent prosecution of pharmaceutical CEO Charles Ackman. Multiple suspects were investigated before Wyatt Ackman was charged.
summary: Mary Costello, living under the false identity of Ella Whitlock, is murdered. Multiple people are investigated and publicly questioned before Wyatt Ackman is charged. Matthew Dooley and an unnamed Mexican man were both publicly accused and threatened by detectives before being cleared. The case pivots to prosecuting Charles Ackman for manslaughter related to opioid deaths.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Detective Jimmy Doyle is shot and killed while off-duty. Initially, evidence points to Ezrie's ex-boyfriend, but he provides information leading to Kendra Daniels, who threatened Scott Gleacher with a gun. Doyle intervened and was killed. Kendra claims self-defense against a racist cop; she's acquitted of 1st-degree manslaughter but convicted of 2nd-degree. Scott Gleacher was briefly a suspect but is later cleared and becomes a cooperating witness after receiving immunity for alleged domestic abuse.

source_notes: Part 3 of crossover event; continues from previous SVU episodes
summary: Mark Sirenko and Daniel Rublev are accused and convicted of murder, sex trafficking, and terrorism. Sirenko pleads guilty and testifies against Rublev. Rublev is killed before trial concludes. No innocent persons are falsely accused - both primary defendants are guilty. While the prosecution strategy changes (cutting deal with Sirenko to convict Rublev), no one is shown or implied to be innocent of the crimes they're accused of.

source_notes: Transcript provided; abortion context central to plot
summary: Becca Carter, daughter of Texas Governor Ron Carter, is murdered in Central Park after traveling to NYC for an abortion. Multiple suspects are investigated before brother Blake Carter is convicted. Steven Cabrera, a dishwasher, is falsely accused based on video proximity and fled when police approached; he was working and late for his second job. An unnamed Black man is also stopped by uniformed officer despite not matching suspect description (white male, baseball cap), appearing to be racial profiling. Both experienced public exposure during police stops/pursuits.

source_notes: Mass shooting in Canal Street subway station; 7 DOA, 11+ injured; suspect John Nelson arrested; federal death penalty case
summary: A white supremacist commits a mass shooting targeting Asian Americans in a subway. Police initially pursue Aaron Rossi, who picked up the shooter's discarded gym bag containing ammunition. Rossi is publicly arrested and accused before being cleared when Jessica Farrell (the actual shooter's ex and mother of his child) provides information leading to the real perpetrator, John Nelson. Jessica is later forced to testify publicly despite promises of confidentiality, exposing her and her daughter to public scrutiny and online harassment.

source_notes: Transcript shows Jerry Ryan (retired detective, godfather to Cosgrove's daughter) possibly planted the necklace evidence in the warehouse to frame Niles Harper for the murder of Christina Watkins. Multiple suspects were cleared during investigation.
summary: Christina Watkins, a published author, is found murdered. Initial suspect Victor Bernini (the chef criticized in her book) is publicly confronted and arrested in a dramatic standoff at his former restaurant, then cleared via alibi at a strip club. Actor Niles Harper becomes the prime suspect after lying about giving Christina a ride; he is arrested and convicted, but the episode strongly implies Detective Jerry Ryan planted the victim's necklace as evidence. Victor Bernini suffered severe public humiliation and arrest despite being innocent of the murder.

source_notes: Transcript shows a law student James Pell blackmailing Professor Ezra Nichols over a slur caught on video. Multiple people become suspects before the actual killer (Nichols' 14-year-old son Cyrus) is revealed.
summary: James Pell is murdered at a boathouse. Detectives initially suspect Sebastian (phone thief), Larry Brand (boathouse worker/fence), April Parks (Pell's ex), and a rival student before arresting Michelle Nichols (professor's wife). Ezra Nichols then falsely confesses. All are later cleared when evidence reveals the actual killer was Cyrus Nichols, the professor's 14-year-old son, who killed Pell to protect his family from blackmail.

source_notes: Transcript shows Perry Sutton (fashion designer) murdered after confronting shoplifter Nick Castillo. The episode focuses on prosecuting Castillo, not wrongful accusations of innocent people.
summary: Fashion designer Perry Sutton is murdered after confronting shoplifter Nick Castillo outside a pharmacy. Detectives initially investigate Sutton's ex-girlfriend Sofia (who had threatened him) but she is quickly cleared via alibi. The episode primarily follows the prosecution of the actual perpetrator Castillo, who has 107 prior arrests. ADA Maroun discovers she previously handled a misdemeanor case against Castillo where victim Jasmine Omari mentioned a gun but the detail was lost in translation/case overload. No innocent person suffers meaningful harm from false accusation in this episode.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Law student James Pell is murdered. Multiple suspects are investigated and publicly accused before the true killer is revealed to be 14-year-old Cyrus Nichols, who killed Pell to protect his father from blackmail. Several innocent people suffered exposure and consequences from false accusations during the investigation.

source_notes: Transcript analysis
summary: Alexander Lockett, former Army colonel and corporate executive, is murdered. Investigation initially focuses on business associates (Sonya Chakrabarti, CFO, and CEO) who had conflicts with him over a fraudulent loan. Both are publicly confronted and investigated but are later cleared. The actual killer is Luke Fallon, a veteran from Lockett's unit seeking revenge over burn pit exposure, though Lockett had actually tried to protect his men.

source_notes: Transcript analysis of S22E09 'The System'
summary: Troy Booker is wrongfully arrested and charged with murder based on a coerced confession and circumstantial evidence (blood on clothes). He is held at Rikers for 18 months without trial. Video evidence later surfaces proving he was rendering aid to the victim, not committing murder. During this wrongful incarceration, he is threatened by a white supremacist inmate. He escapes, killing a corrections officer in the process, and is ultimately convicted of that killing. The episode extensively documents the harm caused by his wrongful prosecution.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: Venezuelan migrant Luis Morales is murdered after witnessing the burial of two construction workers killed in an accident. Multiple people are falsely accused during the investigation: Gavin Stulner (assaulted Morales the day before), Samantha Morris (pulled gun on Morales over alleged theft), and Randall Tully (foreman who buried the bodies). All three faced public exposure—Stulner via police questioning at work, Morris via investigation at her home, and Tully via arrest and public implication in wire-recorded conversation. The actual killer was Ian Belsky, hired by developer Eric Wise.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete with full investigation and trial
summary: Derek Stanton is murdered. Jordan Spall, an ex-con who served time with Stanton at Fishkill, becomes an early suspect based on his refusal to answer Stanton's calls and their history of fighting in prison. He is publicly chased and arrested but later cleared. The actual perpetrator is Jesse Erickson, a prep school student who killed Stanton while high on concentrated cannabis.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: A 14-year-old boy, Eli Barone, is shot and killed by building superintendent Virgil Gilbert when Eli kicks in Gilbert's door as part of a social media 'door-kick challenge' orchestrated by influencer manager Jason Wheeler. Initially, Sean Kapinski (a registered sex offender working as an acting coach) is suspected, and Virgil Gilbert is accused of murder before self-defense is established. The defense falsely accuses Gilbert of having pedophilic interest in Eli during trial. Jason Wheeler is ultimately convicted of manslaughter for causing Eli's death through reckless endangerment of minors.

source_notes: Complex case involving a murder-for-hire by a prosperity gospel pastor. Multiple suspects cleared during investigation.
summary: Emily Wade is murdered outside her apartment. Investigation initially focuses on ex-boyfriend Nathan Brae and then current boyfriend Bobby Gorman, both cleared. Evidence leads to Reverend Henry Sherman driving a church van, who is arrested and charged. Sherman initially cooperates, revealing Pastor Mike Butler hired him to kill Emily after she threatened to expose his fraudulent prosperity gospel scheme. Sherman later recants on the stand (likely due to witness tampering), but other evidence convicts Pastor Mike. Multiple innocent people publicly accused and exposed during the investigation.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: A nightclub shooting kills model Hannah Gray. Police initially suspect rapper King Matisse when they discover he deleted surveillance video, but he did so only to hide that he ran from danger rather than protecting Hannah. Officer Nick Riley initially lies about his arrival time and seeing the shooter, then admits he froze in his patrol car. His testimony convicts Bishop Bell of murder. Riley commits suicide after public exposure of his cowardice. Matisse's reputation is publicly damaged despite being innocent of the shooting.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Dr. Darian Marshall, a heart surgeon, is killed by Brian Burke who claims self-defense based on a false social media post by Daniel Deluca depicting Marshall as an armed, dangerous Black man. The episode also features Detective Jalen Shaw being racially profiled by fellow officers Wagner and Farley, who mistake him for a murder suspect. Shaw faces retaliation when he files a complaint, ultimately being suspended while the officers who profiled him face no consequences.

source_notes: Transcript provided
summary: Jacob Ackerman, a legendary journalist, is murdered while investigating city embezzlement involving a shell company (SiteShield) responsible for fire safety door failures that killed six people. Lucas Hobbs, a neo-Nazi who vandalized Ackerman's house, is initially suspected but cleared. Lamar Cordell, a podcaster who threatened Ackerman online, is also ruled out via alibi. David Costa is eventually convicted of Ackerman's murder, having also killed Deputy Mayor Patricia Simonian to cover up their embezzlement scheme.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Public defender Rachel Bender is murdered. Investigation initially focuses on her clients with criminal backgrounds and violent priors. Luis Cortez, son of a convicted client, is arrested with weapons and Rachel's address but is cleared. Adam Grassley, father of a rape/murder victim whose killer Rachel successfully defended, confronts Rachel publicly but is also cleared. Owen Bardo, another client seen following Rachel, alibis out. Judge Ephraim Raymer, Rachel's ex-boyfriend, is ultimately convicted of her murder.

source_notes: Transcript shows a cult-related murder case where the cult leader Jocelyn Davis is prosecuted for felony murder of Ava Newhall. The true cult leader 'Lodestar' (Zach Elfont) is killed in jail before trial.
summary: Episode focuses on the prosecution of cult leader Jocelyn Davis for the death of Ava Newhall, who died from an infected branding wound. No innocent persons were falsely accused with public exposure or material consequences. The doorman Donnie Preston was questioned about attempted kidnapping but was acting on behalf of Ava's parents to rescue her from the cult, not falsely accused of a crime he didn't commit. All investigated parties were either guilty or complicit in the crimes.

source_notes: Transcript shows murder of Dr. Ryan Bartell by Robert Myers. Case involves controversial medical treatment of transgender child.
summary: Dr. Ryan Bartell is murdered by Robert Myers after providing gender-affirming care (puberty blockers) to Myers's 13-year-old transgender daughter Taylor without the father's consent (though with the mother's consent). The case initially investigates political activists and threats against Bartell's wife, Congresswoman Kristin Bartell, before identifying the true motive. Paul Koening, an Antifa activist who was near the scene, is detained and investigated but proven innocent via DNA.

source_notes: Transcript analysis complete
summary: Jerome Elliot, a billionaire CEO, is murdered in East River Park. Initially, a fired business partner is suspected due to threatening texts and recent conflict. Investigation shifts when it's revealed Elliot's daughter Sophia made abuse allegations at a school retreat. Boyfriend Aaron Cole confesses to the murder, claiming he killed Elliot to protect Sophia. The fired partner is publicly questioned and exposed at work despite being innocent of the murder.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Sarah Baker murdered at art gallery; Madison Platt goes missing. Multiple suspects investigated including Brett Greyson (owed money by Madison), landlord Marquette (spying on Sarah), and Matthew Nelson (Sarah's ex). Greyson was wrongly suspected but had alibi. Marquette arrested for voyeurism but cleared of murder. Nelson ultimately convicted of Sarah's murder.

source_notes: Episode centers on Derek Quinn, a mass shooting survivor and PTSD sufferer who assassinates Senator Alan Chandler. Quinn's trajectory involves intense public exposure through arrest, media coverage, and trial, but he is ultimately convicted (guilty verdict). Since he was found guilty, he does not qualify as innocent and therefore no person_rows are generated.
summary: Senator Alan Chandler is assassinated at his daughter's wedding by Derek Quinn, a history teacher and hero who survived a mass school shooting in 2019. Quinn bought a gun in New Hampshire and shot Chandler twice in the chest after the senator voted against gun-control legislation. Quinn was arrested holding the murder weapon and pled not guilty by reason of insanity, citing severe PTSD from the school shooting where 16 students died in his classroom. The defense argued Quinn couldn't appreciate the wrongfulness of his acts due to trauma. The prosecution, led by ADA Nolan Price (who himself survived a subway shooting), argued this was premeditated political assassination. Quinn was convicted of murder in the first degree. No false suspects or wrongfully accused persons appear in this episode.

source_notes: Transcript shows murder investigation of Celeste Clark; Detective Riley interviewed Bruce Elliot years earlier regarding Olivia Washington disappearance and concluded he was not a suspect. Riley's credibility impeached at trial for prior suspension (punched captain while drinking). Bruce Elliot ultimately convicted of Celeste Clark's murder.
summary: Detective Vincent Riley interviewed Bruce Elliot in 2020 regarding Olivia Washington's disappearance and cleared him as not a suspect. Years later, Elliot is arrested for murdering Celeste Clark and suspected in three other murders including Olivia's. At trial, defense attorney uses Riley's prior conclusion that Elliot was innocent to bolster defense. Prosecution impeaches Riley by revealing his suspension for punching a captain while drinking during the period he interviewed Elliot. Riley is publicly humiliated in court regarding his drinking, personal problems, and professional judgment. Elliot is convicted.

source_notes: Transcript shows Kenneth Cartwright was accused/arrested but was actually guilty of the murder. No qualifying innocent persons identified.
summary: Kenneth Cartwright shoots and kills Dr. Bryan Jeffers and injures a nurse at Mercy General Hospital after his wife Nora and unborn baby die from what he believes was medical negligence. Initially considered as a jumper/suicide risk by Detective Shaw, Cartwright later committed premeditated murder. He confessed ('an eye for an eye') and was convicted. The defense attempted an insanity plea based on race-based traumatic stress, but Cartwright was found guilty. No innocent persons were falsely accused in this episode - Cartwright was the actual perpetrator from the start of the investigation.

source_notes: Transcript appears complete with full dialogue and scene descriptions.
summary: Jonah Barlowe, a stock market figure who became wealthy from the Reels Rental short squeeze, is murdered. Multiple suspects are investigated including his ex-wife and former romantic partners involved in BDSM/financial domination relationships. Dominic Sargento is publicly confronted at his workplace for threatening Barlowe but is cleared. The ex-wife is questioned but also cleared. Jessica Reese, Barlowe's financial dominatrix, is ultimately convicted of his murder after trying to leverage information about actor Evan Connelly's alleged crimes for a plea deal.

source_notes: Full transcript provided
summary: Ellis Joyner, a Black comedian, is strangled to death on the subway. Initially, Malcolm Paige (who had a public altercation with Joyner) is suspected, then Michael Zane (Joyner's boyfriend) becomes a suspect due to threatening messages and prior assault conviction. Both are later cleared. Brandon Arnou, a white elementary school teacher with ties to a white nationalist MMA gym, is arrested and charged with murder but acquitted after a witness corroborates his self-defense claim. Both Paige and Zane suffered public exposure and consequences from being accused.
